conclusion: Consider conditions for total internal reflection: occurs when light travels from higher to lower refractive index and angle of incidence is greater than critical angle.
Light is obliquely incident from air to point A on the transparent medium ball.
Light is initially in air (medium 1) and enters transparent medium ball (medium 2). Refractive index of air (n1) is approximately 1. Refractive index of medium ball (n2) is greater than 1.
Incident angle is given as i.
Light refracts according to Snell's Law: n1 sin(i) = n2 sin(r), where r is angle of refraction inside the medium.
Critical angle for total internal reflection: sin(θc) = n1/n2.
Total internal reflection occurs if angle of incidence inside medium (angle of refraction r) is greater than critical angle θc.
Light enters sphere at angle i and refracts inside sphere. For total internal reflection at inner surface, angle r must be greater than θc.
Angle of incidence i is not directly relevant to total internal reflection condition at inner surface.

Light will not be totally internally reflected when emitted from inside sphere because it moves from higher to lower refractive index and angle of incidence inside sphere must be greater than critical angle.
Final answer: No, the light will not be totally reflected when emitted from inside the sphere.
